subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Overconfidence Effect: The Founder's Blind Spot
description: A fast breakdown of Overconfidence Effect: The Founder's Blind Spot for builders.

hook.text: 93% of founders believe their startup will succeed. The actual success rate is about 10%.

buildup.text: The overconfidence effect makes people overestimate their knowledge, abilities, and predictions.

discovery.text: In entrepreneurs, it's amplified. The optimism that drives them to start also blinds them to danger.

twist.text: Some overconfidence is necessary. Without it, nobody would ever start a company.

climax.text: Research calls this the 'optimism paradox'â€”enough delusion to begin, but enough realism to survive.

punchline.text: A little delusion gets you started. Too much gets you killed.

quiz.question: What is the 'optimism paradox' in entrepreneurship?
options: Founders need enough optimism to start but enough realism to survive
